source.raw_text:
The Turkish Get-Up (TGU) is a full-body, multi-step movement from lying to standing and back, working muscles like shoulders (deltoids, rotator cuff), core (abs, obliques, erectors), glutes, legs (quads, hamstrings, calves), and back (traps, lats) for stability, strength, and mobility, with movement patterns emphasizing rotational control, hip extension, spinal stability, and overhead stabilization through distinct phases like bridging, sweeping, and half-kneeling. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Shoulders & Arms: Deltoids, rotator cuff, traps, lats, triceps (for stabilization and pressing). 
• Core: Rectus abdominis, obliques, transverse abdominis, erector spinae (for spinal rigidity and rotation). 
• Hips & Glutes: Gluteus maximus, medius, minimus (for hip extension and pelvic stability). 
• Legs: Quadriceps, hamstrings, calves (for stabilization and driving up). 
• Grip: Forearm muscles (to hold the weight). [2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Patterns & Phases 
The TGU involves a sequence of controlled transitions, requiring coordinated effort in each phase. 

1. Starting Position: Lying down, arm extended overhead, knee bent, foot flat, other arm out. 
2. Roll to Elbow: Pushing through the foot and hand to lift onto the elbow. 
3. Hand Support: Pressing into the hand to lift the torso upright. 
4. Bridge (Hip Lift): Lifting hips off the floor (glutes, hamstrings). 
5. Leg Sweep: Sweeping the back leg through to a half-kneeling position (hip mobility, glutes, core). 
6. Knee to Stand: Driving up to a tall, standing lunge (quads, glutes). 
7. Reverse: The entire sequence is reversed with the same control and stability, emphasizing the core and shoulder as you lower back down. [1, 2, 5, 9, 10, 11]  

Key Functional Aspects 

• Stability: The weight overhead acts as a stability challenge for the shoulder girdle and core. 
• Mobility: Requires hip and thoracic spine mobility. 
• Strength: Builds full-body strength through isometric holds and dynamic movement. 
• Coordination: Integrates multiple joints and muscle groups. [1, 2, 3, 4, 7]
